title: Creator of gold lavatory stolen from Blenheim Palace hopes theft was 'inspired by Robin Hood'
text:
'America', a fully-working solid gold lavatory, created by artist Maurizio Cattelan, seen at Blenheim Palace two days before the audacious theft. Sept 12, 2019. - Getty Images Europe

The artist that created the gold lavatory stolen from Blenheim Palace has said he hopes the theft was "inspired by Robin Hood" and denies it was a Banksy-style prank.

Speaking for the first time since the burglary, Maurizio Cattelan said the artwork “was the one percent for the 99 percent, and I hope it still is. I want to be positive and think the robbery is a kind of Robin Hood-inspired action.”

His first thought had been that the news was another great art world prank, similar to when street artist Banksy shredded a £1 million painting that had just been sold at auction.

“At first, when they woke me up with the news I thought it was a prank: Who’s so stupid to steal a toilet?” Mr Cattelan told the New York Times.

“I had forgotten for a second that it was made out of gold.”

The comments came as the Chief Executive of Blenheim Palace, the Oxfordshire birthplace of Winston Churchill, has said he fears the 18-karat gold lavatory, titled ‘America’ may have been melted down by thieves.

Dominic Hare said the value of the raw materials would have made the artwork attractive to criminals and hopes the notoriety of the case would “immortalise” the artist because of the “moronic act” he told the Telegraph.

“It’s clear that the raw materials in this case are a higher proportion of the finished artwork than if you took a large painting and disassembled or destroyed it."

Police confirmed a 66-year old man held in connection with the burglary remains in custody in the West Mercia area.

Mr Hare did not think the arrested man was an employee of Blenheim Palace and had no idea how police had connected him to the lavatory.

“Our imagination runs wild, but they are still holding him so they must be convinced there’s a clear connection.”

He said any ticket holders for the exhibition, that runs to October 26, would be reimbursed for the three-minute time slot visitors had been able to book in the fully functioning lavatory.

“They could fully perform on it if they wished, but most people couldn’t time it that way so they just took selfies,” he said.
description: The artist that created the gold lavatory stolen from Blenheim Palace has said he hopes the theft was "inspired by Robin Hood" and denies it was a Banksy-style prank.
